instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
hey guys. this one came from another store and there has been a previous repair attempt. I only noticed because L7210 was missing I have no other history and suspect no prior liquid damage.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> has 20v present but both <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on F7040 both showing 0.6v. I removed F7040 and measured both to ground and short is on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I soldered a wire to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and put around 8v through - it was drawing close to 1.8A but no heat? Should i go higher?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Where did you hear to inject in such crazy manner?
Always search first if no high-side MOSFET is short on any secondary power supply.
Because if not, you can directly inject high voltage into a low voltage rail!
Also NEVER start with hihg voltage, even if you are in the main power rail.
Post the exact value for that short.
Then search all the (big) coils for similar value.
This way you can detect a shorted high-side MOSFET, if exists.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey informaticos i started with lower voltage with no success so i went up until it got to 8. i will test tomorrow mornign and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: .7ohm pm <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Now check if other big coil has the same value.
If any found check then between it and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If you get 0.000-0.001 means shorted MOSFET. If you decide to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, do not exceed 120% of that coil.
If you get 0.014-0.015 means no short. In such case you can inject even 8V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_3H</SIGNAL>.
Hoiwever, always start with low voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ahhhhh i see what you are saying. thanks informaticos

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: In case of shorted MOSFET, remove it and then you don't have a low limit for voltage injection anymore...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ok. short is not on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> its on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Those are literally the exact same rail...try this remove the CPU heatsink and use freeze spray if possible. Inject voltage on pin 2 of F7040 at 1.8 volts and see if by chance the CPU die evaporates first. If so, dead CPU. If not, then something else must absolutely get hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: John must i use freeze spray?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
ok tried thermal cam and freeze spray. done the entire board both sides no go.

i have previously removed some components that i have yet  to put back on in pursuit of finding the short.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 3.4ohm short to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You don't have to use freeze spray, but it helps. Something I'm seeing more and more on these new ones is a dead short to ground through the PCH die of the CPU. Inspect that. Also inspect if any cap gets obviously hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: hmmm no caps getting hot. anything else you can recommend?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Like I said, I wouldn't be surprised if it's the die on the CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: anyway to test?>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Freeze spray is best with canned air upside down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 3.4ohm short to ground."
Did you remove <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> to confirm that?
Check now the exact value at L7210/30/90, L7410/30, L7900/60, L8000/50.
This way you can discard a shorted MOSFET.
If is not the case, you can inject voltage without fear.
That rail has many filter caps, and also goes to <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 43014"]"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 3.4ohm short to ground."
Did you remove <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> to confirm that?
[/QUOTE]

yes

I have also removed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> but i will check mosfets.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Now post resistance value between L7210/30 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>.
Lower than 3 ohm (aprox 2 ohm) means one of corresponding MOSFETs is shorted.
In such case, 95% dead CPU.
If you get aprox 4.5-5 ohm you are lucky, CPU can still be good.
Then should be one cap which must heat injecting voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
unfortaunalty it measures around 1.7ohm on both

cpu dead?
makes sense as one of the mosfets was missing when it came in so previous guy took a look and it is same scenario.
